thread.title: Doom 3 v1.3.1 freezes - Win 7 x64, AMD Radeon HD 6700

post.author: Stubbsy
post.body:
Hi all,

I've been trying to get Doom 3 v1.3.1 working on my girlfriend's PC - it's running Window 7 64 bit with an AMD Radeon HD 6700 series card. It runs the game flawlessly on Ultra settings pretty much maxed out (I never turned on AA), and experiences no slow down or performance issues whatsoever.

Problem is, the game completely freezes at seemingly random intervals. The sound will carry on for a bit, then the screen goes back. I can ctrl+alt+del and then end task, but it doesn't offer any kind of error log or prompt. Longest game time I've managed in one go is about an hour, but sometimes it crashes after a couple of minutes, and usually within 20 minutes.

Installed in order - Doom 3 retail, followed by ROE including the v1.2 patch, then patched to v1.3.1, then installed Opencoop.

System

Below is the summary report from Aida 64 Extreme Addition. Can provide more reports if need be.

I've tried

Compatibility
- Compatibility mode for XP sp2 and sp3, and Vista
- Disabling visual themes, desktop composition, and display scaling on high DPI
- Running as Administrator
- Disabling Windows firewall and Anti Virus
- Making an exception in Windows DEP (fixed some of my older games)

Graphics card
- Tried the latest two drivers 12-10 (9.2.0.0) and 12-11 Beta (9.10.8.0), with and without CCC installed
- Rolled all the way back one by one through 8.982.0.0, 8.980.0.0, 8.961.0.0, 8.950.0.0, 8.930.0.0, 8.861.0.0 and 8.850.0.0, each without CCC installed
- Used Driver Fusion to clear all traces of ATI/AMD and deleted all folders, then ran a fresh install of the latest drivers
- Used SlimDrivers to detect and update all other drivers on the PC. About 7 updates were found and updated, including Network & Sound Adapters. Everything is now up-to-date.

Motherboard
- Found the motherboard on the Gigabyte website - downloaded and installed the latest AMD Chipset Driver.
- Attemped to download and install BIOS FFd, FE and FD in turn, but each one said it's not compatible with 64 bit Windows. I've got no idea how to get one that is compatible, since there is no drop-down to select Windows version etc.

Widescreen - Followed this Widescreen guide to set the resolution to 1920*1080 in 16:9 aspect.

I've reinstalled the game or deleted doomconfig.cfg several times inbetween/after these fixes.


Any help or advice would be massively appreciated

Many thanks,
Shaun

post.author: Sir Random
post.body:
Since the game runs fine before freezing, I doubt if there's any compatibilty/driver issues.
Try running the game with lower gfx settings (640x480, low detail). If it runs fine at these settings, then I suspect your gfx card may be overheating.

post.author: Stubbsy
post.body:
Hi Sir Random, thanks for the reply.

Have just put the settings down to Low Quality, 640x480, and all Advanced Options turned off.

First attempt - crashed in the normal way within seconds of booting
Second attempt - it crashed in a completely different way to normal. Within about 30 seconds of loading, the screen filled with dark blue vertical tubes; the sound continued for a second and then went really distorted. After about 5 seconds of this, the computer rebooted itself.
Third attempt - almost the same as the first - lasted about 10 seconds then crashed in the normal way

Very weird what happened the second time - that hasn't happened any of the previous 50+ times I've tried...

This, coupled with the fact that the PC can run some newer games such as L4D2 on max, had led me to believe it wasn't a graphics card overheating problem.

Thanks again! Any other ideas?

post.author: reckless
post.body:
Do other OpenGL games run ? it might be one of Doom3's quirks with radeon cards.
One of the big showstoppers for many ATI users have been the catalyst AI (for some reason it completly screws up on idtech engines) theres some posts here somewhere
on how to turn it off, you can try that and let us know the result though normally the games refuse to run at all its worth a try.
Else it can be a number of things like buggy driver revisions / faulty ram etc. It can be a bitch at times to hunt down these things.
One particularly crazy bug i had with my old 8800 gtx was random crashing in world of warcraft, it took 3 years before i found out that my mainboards chipset
was the culprit. What happened was that the card was pretty close to the northbridge and the 8800 gets really hot, well so does the X58 chipset from intel and the combination was not good as my northbridge idled at 80" and shot up to 120" when in warcraft so the chipset started to auto clock down before it burned and my gfx card didnt like that one bit

Get game demos. Q4's a good one to test, they did make some engine changes. Q3A has a demo, Steel Storm has a demo, some of the UT games have demos. Those are great to diagnose issues. IE Q3A isn't the latest OGL, but if it works fine then it's something newer games use.

post.author: Stubbsy
post.body:
Update.

Done some more testing. It seems now with Catalyst AI disabled the game is a lot more stable, and I'm quite tempted to say that the error I was experiencing before has been resolved. I even managed to host an Opencoop game from the PC, have my laptop connect, and the two sat idle for 1.75 hours without crashing while I did other things.

However, there's a catch (there always is... ). I'm now experiencing a more generic error that I have seen with other games, but unfortunately causes Doom 3 to hang in the same way

Quote:
Display driver has stopped responding and recovered


The nature of the crash has changed. Now, instead of simply a freeze and then black screen, it freezes then goes to the Doom 3 grey colour that shows during startup, and shows the Windows 'loading' cursor locked in the centre of the screen. It hangs like this for about 5 seconds, then brings up the 'Close the Program' vs 'Wait for the program to respond' dialog. The cursor is still locked, so I have to use Task Manager to kill it as normal.

Event Viewer informs me that there was a 'Warning' Event 4101 Display - 'Display driver amdkmdap stopped responding and has successfully recovered.', accompanied just short of a minute later by the usual 1002 Application Hang.


On the advice of some of the earlier posts I installed Serious Sam: The Second Encounter yesterday, and ran it in high quality 1600*1200 OpenGL. Managed to play for ~75 minutes before experiencing the same driver warning > hang crash; launched again and it happened with 5 minutes; then a third time and managed about 90 minutes before crashing again. Seems quite random, but good news I guess is that it all seems to due to display adapter error in Windows itself rather than problems with the games / OpenGL

As mentioned earlier, I have experienced this error on two other games on this PC, but in both cases the game has flickered in and out for about 5-10 seconds before completely recovering. Frustrating, but I would take it for Doom 3 over completely killing the application! It happens most frequently (perhaps every 15-30 minutes) when she plays Civ 4, and has happened maybe 4 or 5 times during L4D2... but that's of over 80 hours of gameplay!


Any have any other Doom 3 players experienced/resolved this problem?

I've done some research and followed tips from articles/posts on atikmdag, ComputerTipsFree and HardwareHeaven, but nothing has convincingly made a difference so far

I've tried:
- Creating both Dword and Qword registry entires called TdrDelay, and setting the value to 10, 1 or 0.
- Disabling UAC (User Account Control)
- Checked and Aero themes were already disabled
- Checked that update KB952287 wasn't installed... or I can't find it if it is!
- Underclocked the GPU settings in CCC from default 840MHz to the minimum (on the slider) of 775MHz.
- Overriden the Fan Control in CCC and set to 80%.
- A fix involving msconfig > Boot > Advanced Options... and setting overrides on Number of Processors (6) and Max Memory (16384), and restarted. Windows failed to boot following this, and got stuck in a loop of failing to repair itself and restarting, so I had to go in using Safe Mode and revert these changes


Launched a game of Opencoop between most of these attempts last night and played for usually between 10-40 minutes. However, managed to play SS:SE this morning for 90 minutes without a crash.


Any more ideas? Someone here must have seen this before, if not in Doom, then in some form?! I feel we've made progress anyway - thanks so much for all the help, very much appreciated!!

post.author: reckless
post.body:
Yep thats a TDR error i had that to with warcraft theres a hack out there somewhere to set some specific registry editor flags to turn this feature off but be warned if
some hardware is really faulty you might end up crashing your PC for good (BSOD). In my case it was the heat on my northbridge that triggered a TDR because at the temperatures it ran at timings got all screwy. I had to use that regedit hack for several years untill i found out what caused it.

Rule of thumb if you get this error then something is indeed screwing up and you need to investigate every possible fault untill it runs stable,
this can be a lenghty process but you are not alone the things posted above are pretty good markers of what can be wrong.

If youre not savy with opening your laptop get a friend who has more experience with it to do it, and check for overheating components (good marker if its hot enough that you risk burning your hand then its a problem and you need to get some more airflow to that part with fans, or invest in better coolers).

Windows 7 has a ram tester also you can try to run it only takes one bad block of ram to ruin your day
Get CCleaner also and let it take out the thrash that builds up in windows over time, use it to clean your registry and delete temporary files (it's free).

A fast way to check heat problems without investing in PC fans or coolers is to take of the side of the laptop and have a regular fan like you use in the summer blowing directly into the now open cabinet. If that makes it more stable then you know what your next investment is

Still, a few questions come to mind as regards to overheating. Firstly, why would it happen so frequently when she plays Civalization 4 of all games? As it happens, it's the only game that shows any consistency in when the error occurs, since it pretty much always happens during the Diplomacy screen which is a 3D cutscene-like display featuring a character addressing the player. Something doesn't add up when a primitive cutscene like this causes the error every time, while even top-notch D3 lasts 40 minutes before the crash!

Secondly - do you know if the Temperature gauge on the AMD OverDrive screen of CCC is accurate? This shows the idle temperature of the GPU to be 32-40; and I've checked it immediately after every time D3 has crashed and it's never been higher than 48. As ever, I'll admit I'm very new to all this, but a quick Google search suggests these are very low temperatures and certainly nothing to be worried about!

theres a hack out there somewhere to set some specific registry editor flags to turn this feature off

As a side note, I noticed looking at Event Viewer that with all the times it crashed yesterday, the 4101 Display warning has not been accompanied by the 1002 Application Hang any more It seems that the display warning alone is killing it now...

Thanks.

post.author: reckless
post.body:
Aye thats what TDR is for it keeps things from hanging or crashing the pc.
Turning it off might let you play but it might also cause the program to hang again only way to know is to try.

Overheating can be caused by a program utilizing lots of cpu time, warcrafts engine is very old though they updated parts of it it still gobbles up cpu time like popcorn
Doom3 also makes good use of the cpu as the engine was written back when hardware shading was still in its infancy and many effects had to be done on the cpu instead of
as today where the gpu handles most of that.

Strangely the mainboard i had back then was also from gigabyte
i had hoped they had learned there lesson and mounted some beefier coolers on the chipsets cause the one on mine was seriously not able to cool the damn x58 chipset hehe.

I managed to dig up the site where i found the tdr registry hack

http://social.technet.microsoft.com/Forums/en/w7itproappcompat/thread/9b90d3e4-8456-4cfd-8138-995947c62a05

Hi all,

I've been trying to get Doom 3 v1.3.1 working on my girlfriend's PC - it's running Window 7 64 bit with an AMD Radeon HD 6700 series card. It runs the game flawlessly on Ultra settings pretty much maxed out (I never turned on AA), and experiences no slow down or performance issues whatsoever.

I've tried

Compatibility
- Compatibility mode for XP sp2 and sp3, and Vista
- Disabling visual themes, desktop composition, and display scaling on high DPI
- Running as Administrator
- Disabling Windows firewall and Anti Virus
- Making an exception in Windows DEP (fixed some of my older games)

Graphics card
- Tried the latest two drivers 12-10 (9.2.0.0) and 12-11 Beta (9.10.8.0), with and without CCC installed
- Rolled all the way back one by one through 8.982.0.0, 8.980.0.0, 8.961.0.0, 8.950.0.0, 8.930.0.0, 8.861.0.0 and 8.850.0.0, each without CCC installed
- Used Driver Fusion to clear all traces of ATI/AMD and deleted all folders, then ran a fresh install of the latest drivers
- Used SlimDrivers to detect and update all other drivers on the PC. About 7 updates were found and updated, including Network & Sound Adapters. Everything is now up-to-date.

Motherboard
- Found the motherboard on the Gigabyte website - downloaded and installed the latest AMD Chipset Driver.
- Attemped to download and install BIOS FFd, FE and FD in turn, but each one said it's not compatible with 64 bit Windows. I've got no idea how to get one that is compatible, since there is no drop-down to select Windows version etc.

Widescreen - Followed this Widescreen guide to set the resolution to 1920*1080 in 16:9 aspect.

I've reinstalled the game or deleted doomconfig.cfg several times inbetween/after these fixes.


Any help or advice would be massively appreciated

Many thanks,
Shaun

post.author: Sir Random
post.body:
Since the game runs fine before freezing, I doubt if there's any compatibilty/driver issues.
Try running the game with lower gfx settings (640x480, low detail). If it runs fine at these settings, then I suspect your gfx card may be overheating.

post.author: Stubbsy
post.body:
Hi Sir Random, thanks for the reply.

Have just put the settings down to Low Quality, 640x480, and all Advanced Options turned off.

First attempt - crashed in the normal way within seconds of booting
Second attempt - it crashed in a completely different way to normal. Within about 30 seconds of loading, the screen filled with dark blue vertical tubes; the sound continued for a second and then went really distorted. After about 5 seconds of this, the computer rebooted itself.
Third attempt - almost the same as the first - lasted about 10 seconds then crashed in the normal way

Very weird what happened the second time - that hasn't happened any of the previous 50+ times I've tried...


Also worth mentioning - I had dropped the settings previously to High or Medium with some details turned off, and found that it crashed relatively quickly - whereas the time when I managed to play for an hour straight had been on fully maxed out Ultra. This, coupled with the fact that the PC can run some newer games such as L4D2 on max, had led me to believe it wasn't a graphics card overheating problem.

Thanks again! Any other ideas?

post.author: Sir Random
post.body:
Stubbsy wrote:
Within about 30 seconds of loading, the screen filled with dark blue vertical tubes;

Did it look anything like this?


That would indicate gfx card issues.

post.author: Stubbsy
post.body:
Hmm... not exactly.

I couldn't find anything online that looks like it, so the attached is my rudimentary attempt to re-create it using PSP! It filled the whole screen - there was no trace of the Windows desktop or interface etc like in your screenshot.

Pic (couldn't get the img tags to work)

As I say, this is the first and only time it's done that in well over 50 attempts under different settings. Guess it could all be the same root cause though...?

Thanks.

post.author: reckless
post.body:
Do other OpenGL games run ? it might be one of Doom3's quirks with radeon cards.
One of the big showstoppers for many ATI users have been the catalyst AI (for some reason it completly screws up on idtech engines) theres some posts here somewhere
on how to turn it off, you can try that and let us know the result though normally the games refuse to run at all its worth a try.
Else it can be a number of things like buggy driver revisions / faulty ram etc. It can be a bitch at times to hunt down these things.
One particularly crazy bug i had with my old 8800 gtx was random crashing in world of warcraft, it took 3 years before i found out that my mainboards chipset
was the culprit. What happened was that the card was pretty close to the northbridge and the 8800 gets really hot, well so does the X58 chipset from intel and the combination was not good as my northbridge idled at 80" and shot up to 120" when in warcraft so the chipset started to auto clock down before it burned and my gfx card didnt like that one bit

post.author: The Happy Friar
post.body:
Use a digital camera to take a pic please, that should work.

What other games can you run? If it's a GPU (or something) overheating, other games could cause it too.

post.author: BloodRayne
post.body:
Check your event log for any errors, that will indicate in which area to look.
It could just as well be an audio-driver issue, or a direct-input issue with your mouse-drivers etc.etc..

The faulting DLL (and perhaps an error message) will tells us more about which area to look at.

post.author: Stubbsy
post.body:
Thanks for the replies.

reckless wrote:
One of the big showstoppers for many ATI users have been the catalyst AI (for some reason it completly screws up on idtech engines) theres some posts here somewhere
on how to turn it off, you can try that and let us know the result though normally the games refuse to run at all its worth a try.


Aha, I haven't tried this :) As I said in my first post, I have tried all of the last 9 drivers, including the latest Beta, without Catalyst Control Center installed at all, but I haven't tried disabling Catalyst AI. Will try soon and post the results - thanks.

Ps - bet it was a good feeling when you beat your 3 year old bug! :wink:


reckless wrote:
Do other OpenGL games run ?


Just looked up at list of OpenGL games, and I'm not sure I've run that many on that machine yet, and certainly nothing recent that will really 'test' it. I could install Deus Ex, Serious Sam, Rt Castle Wolfenstein or Quake 4 (which I was avoiding because it's also idtech 4) to test it if need be since these are OpenGL.


The Happy Friar wrote:
Use a digital camera to take a pic please, that should work.


Of the blue screen error? Might be tricky - it's still only occurred that once, and I don't have much to go by on what made that error appear instead of the other one! :? I will keep a camera handy and try to snap it should it happen again, but it does look pretty much identical to that pic I posted. If I've misunderstood and you meant the normal error, there's really nothing to take a photo of. The screen just freezes, then goes black - there's no visual abnormalities whatsoever.


The Happy Friar wrote:
What other games can you run? If it's a GPU (or something) overheating, other games could cause it too.


As I say, the only other game which could really 'test' the PC properly is Left For Dead 2 - which it can run absolutely maxed out with no slow down at all, even on busy/intense online games. :roll:


BloodRayne wrote:
Check your event log for any errors, that will indicate in which area to look.


Are you referring to 'Event Viewer'? Had to do a quick search as I've somehow not used this before! :oops: Thanks for the tip - I'll give it a go.

post.author: The Happy Friar
post.body:
Get game demos. Q4's a good one to test, they did make some engine changes. Q3A has a demo, Steel Storm has a demo, some of the UT games have demos. Those are great to diagnose issues. IE Q3A isn't the latest OGL, but if it works fine then it's something newer games use.

on the ATI Catylist AI "bug", Nvidia has the same thing just nobody mentions it. The multi-core optimization breaks lots of games, seems to be OGL. I'm assuming the AI & that do the same kind of thing.

post.author: reckless
post.body:
Quote:
The screen just freezes, then goes black


That was the exact bug i had with warcraft

Check the chipset cooler nearest the GFX card just touch it but be warned i got blisters when i did that with mine, if its that hot then get an antec spotcool (small fan that can be mounted anywhere and has a flexible arm so you can point it even at otherwise hard to reach places) use that to cool the chipset down some. Worked for me.

If you got a spare fan somewhere that fits thats also good

As a sidenote some realtek soundcard drivers can also cause this so check that to in case you got one.

post.author: Stubbsy
post.body:
Update.

Done some more testing. It seems now with Catalyst AI disabled the game is a lot more stable, and I'm quite tempted to say that the error I was experiencing before has been resolved. I even managed to host an Opencoop game from the PC, have my laptop connect, and the two sat idle for 1.75 hours without crashing while I did other things.

However, there's a catch (there always is... ). I'm now experiencing a more generic error that I have seen with other games, but unfortunately causes Doom 3 to hang in the same way

Quote:
Display driver has stopped responding and recovered


The nature of the crash has changed. Now, instead of simply a freeze and then black screen, it freezes then goes to the Doom 3 grey colour that shows during startup, and shows the Windows 'loading' cursor locked in the centre of the screen. It hangs like this for about 5 seconds, then brings up the 'Close the Program' vs 'Wait for the program to respond' dialog. The cursor is still locked, so I have to use Task Manager to kill it as normal.

Event Viewer informs me that there was a 'Warning' Event 4101 Display - 'Display driver amdkmdap stopped responding and has successfully recovered.', accompanied just short of a minute later by the usual 1002 Application Hang.


On the advice of some of the earlier posts I installed Serious Sam: The Second Encounter yesterday, and ran it in high quality 1600*1200 OpenGL. Managed to play for ~75 minutes before experiencing the same driver warning > hang crash; launched again and it happened with 5 minutes; then a third time and managed about 90 minutes before crashing again. Seems quite random, but good news I guess is that it all seems to due to display adapter error in Windows itself rather than problems with the games / OpenGL

As mentioned earlier, I have experienced this error on two other games on this PC, but in both cases the game has flickered in and out for about 5-10 seconds before completely recovering. Frustrating, but I would take it for Doom 3 over completely killing the application! It happens most frequently (perhaps every 15-30 minutes) when she plays Civ 4, and has happened maybe 4 or 5 times during L4D2... but that's of over 80 hours of gameplay!


Any have any other Doom 3 players experienced/resolved this problem?

I've done some research and followed tips from articles/posts on atikmdag, ComputerTipsFree and HardwareHeaven, but nothing has convincingly made a difference so far

I've tried:
- Creating both Dword and Qword registry entires called TdrDelay, and setting the value to 10, 1 or 0.
- Disabling UAC (User Account Control)
- Checked and Aero themes were already disabled
- Checked that update KB952287 wasn't installed... or I can't find it if it is!
- Underclocked the GPU settings in CCC from default 840MHz to the minimum (on the slider) of 775MHz.
- Overriden the Fan Control in CCC and set to 80%.
- A fix involving msconfig > Boot > Advanced Options... and setting overrides on Number of Processors (6) and Max Memory (16384), and restarted. Windows failed to boot following this, and got stuck in a loop of failing to repair itself and restarting, so I had to go in using Safe Mode and revert these changes


Launched a game of Opencoop between most of these attempts last night and played for usually between 10-40 minutes. However, managed to play SS:SE this morning for 90 minutes without a crash.


Any more ideas? Someone here must have seen this before, if not in Doom, then in some form?! I feel we've made progress anyway - thanks so much for all the help, very much appreciated!!

post.author: reckless
post.body:
Yep thats a TDR error i had that to with warcraft theres a hack out there somewhere to set some specific registry editor flags to turn this feature off but be warned if
some hardware is really faulty you might end up crashing your PC for good (BSOD). In my case it was the heat on my northbridge that triggered a TDR because at the temperatures it ran at timings got all screwy. I had to use that regedit hack for several years untill i found out what caused it.

Rule of thumb if you get this error then something is indeed screwing up and you need to investigate every possible fault untill it runs stable,
this can be a lenghty process but you are not alone the things posted above are pretty good markers of what can be wrong.

If youre not savy with opening your laptop get a friend who has more experience with it to do it, and check for overheating components (good marker if its hot enough that you risk burning your hand then its a problem and you need to get some more airflow to that part with fans, or invest in better coolers).

Windows 7 has a ram tester also you can try to run it only takes one bad block of ram to ruin your day
Get CCleaner also and let it take out the thrash that builds up in windows over time, use it to clean your registry and delete temporary files (it's free).

A fast way to check heat problems without investing in PC fans or coolers is to take of the side of the laptop and have a regular fan like you use in the summer blowing directly into the now open cabinet. If that makes it more stable then you know what your next investment is

A fast way to check heat problems without investing in PC fans or coolers is to take of the side of the laptop and have a regular fan like you use in the summer blowing directly into the now open cabinet. If that makes it more stable then you know what your next investment is


Haha, I've already stationed a big ol' desk fan next to the tower pointing at the vents - just haven't taken the case off yet!

Still, a few questions come to mind as regards to overheating. Firstly, why would it happen so frequently when she plays Civalization 4 of all games? As it happens, it's the only game that shows any consistency in when the error occurs, since it pretty much always happens during the Diplomacy screen which is a 3D cutscene-like display featuring a character addressing the player. Something doesn't add up when a primitive cutscene like this causes the error every time, while even top-notch D3 lasts 40 minutes before the crash!

Secondly - do you know if the Temperature gauge on the AMD OverDrive screen of CCC is accurate? This shows the idle temperature of the GPU to be 32-40; and I've checked it immediately after every time D3 has crashed and it's never been higher than 48. As ever, I'll admit I'm very new to all this, but a quick Google search suggests these are very low temperatures and certainly nothing to be worried about!

As a side note, I noticed looking at Event Viewer that with all the times it crashed yesterday, the 4101 Display warning has not been accompanied by the 1002 Application Hang any more It seems that the display warning alone is killing it now...

Thanks.

post.author: reckless
post.body:
Aye thats what TDR is for it keeps things from hanging or crashing the pc.
Turning it off might let you play but it might also cause the program to hang again only way to know is to try.

Overheating can be caused by a program utilizing lots of cpu time, warcrafts engine is very old though they updated parts of it it still gobbles up cpu time like popcorn
Doom3 also makes good use of the cpu as the engine was written back when hardware shading was still in its infancy and many effects had to be done on the cpu instead of
as today where the gpu handles most of that.

Strangely the mainboard i had back then was also from gigabyte
i had hoped they had learned there lesson and mounted some beefier coolers on the chipsets cause the one on mine was seriously not able to cool the damn x58 chipset hehe.

I managed to dig up the site where i found the tdr registry hack

http://social.technet.microsoft.com/Forums/en/w7itproappcompat/thread/9b90d3e4-8456-4cfd-8138-995947c62a05
